text:
Hi Superpath friends,

I would love some advice for a (business) journalist/editor looking to break out into an in-house content writer-type role. 

For some background: I’ve worked for 6 years at a digital media startup that covers business (all sectors) in Atlantic Canada. On top of the traditional reporting/editing duties, I also help develop and create sponsored content and help edit/produce the publication’s two podcasts. I actually setup the company’s podcast network. Before my current company I also worked for the national public broadcaster (CBC) as a reporter, web writer and producer. My experience is pretty diverse. 

As you probably know, a journalist’s skillset transfers very well for these types of jobs. I’ve been getting interviews and have gotten pretty far along in the process in some of them, but ultimately they are looking with someone with more “experience” in that space, or something along those lines. But in most cases, they’ve instead asked if they could reach out to me for freelance work though, so I don’t think I’m completely missing the mark at least haha!

I absolutely plan on taking on Freelance work and building up my “content creator” portfolio more. But I was wondering if anyone has any other advice for how someone with my background could better position myself for these types of roles? 

If you’re a former journalist, how did you go about making this switch? If you’re a company that hires these types of roles, what would you want to see from someone with my kind of resume? Etc.
:pray:
Thank you so much! @

text:
Although I haven't done FT journalism - early in my career I did freelance journalism so I'm somewhat familiar with the dynamics.

There's  a ton I can say on the topic, but the key takeaways I have from my career are:

1. In most industries companies care more about your ability to synthetize information effectively to target audiences rather than to actually know the material. My work with Iron Mountain writing about compliance got me into Airbnb as a strategist to develop host education content.  My work with TEDxSanFrancsico featuring pop culture references got me a role as a strategist at eBay in the Payments division (which is very regulated).
2. When hiring, you can be an amazing writer, but from what I've seen, and in my direct hiring experience, if you don't have interpersonal skills, then you'll be passed over. Collaboration is essential in marketing and you need to be able to process feedback, be diplomatic when getting pushback, and also able to handle conflict (e.g. different teams have different priorities, etc.) effectively.
3. Surgical attention to detail is essential. In my role at eBay, my work has visibility from the C-Level to average sellers. Whether something is for internal use only, or goes to our sellers, precision is key. Not just line edits but also knowing nuances (e.g. legal will not let us say "when the buyer pays" but we can say "when the buyer's payment is confirmed")
Overall, I'd say having a journalism background is advantageous for many because the skills significantly overlap with those requirements. In interviews, the key thing to focus on is what the company is looking to achieve, and then call out how your past experience relates.

text:
As someone who has hired people from journalism roles as content writers or content managers, one thing that always stands out to me is when the applicant is able to tie their work to a number. If you’re able to connect your past journalism work experience to a tangible business metric (even if it’s a newspaper or publication) you have my attention. 

Speaking specifically to what you said, I would really prop up your podcast experience - so many B2B companies are trying to get in the podcast game, and that is a real asset for a company looking for someone who has that plus a content skillset!
